articles.title: Ephemeris
articles.summary: This ephemeris outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) activities for October, November, and December, featuring a variety of events including general and board meetings, multiple outdoor and indoor star parties, and a Halloween party. It also announces a potential convoy for the STS-5 space shuttle landing and provides membership and contact information for the association. The scheduled events include talks on topics like lightning and relativity, as well as opportunities for mirror grinding.

articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: This article from "Observations" details the San Jose Astronomical Association's November General Meeting, featuring Leon Salanave's talk on lightning photography and atmospheric physics. It also announces a club initiative for a group purchase of inexpensive computers and highlights the increasing role of technology in amateur astronomy. Additionally, the piece provides resources for beginners, including an ASP telescope guide and SJAA's telescope-building classes and star parties.

articles.title: A NOTE ON PUPIL SIZE OF EYES
articles.summary: This article discusses the actual maximum pupil size of the human eye, noting that it can be significantly larger (9-10mm) than the commonly cited "book" value (6-7mm), especially under dark conditions. The author emphasizes the importance of accurate pupil size measurement for amateur astronomers, as it dictates the lowest efficiently usable magnification of a telescope to avoid light loss. The article also touches on methods for measuring pupil size and clarifies that large pupil diameter does not automatically equate to keen retinal dark adaptation.

articles.title: SJAA BOARD OF DIRECTORS
articles.summary: This document lists the members of the SJAA Board of Directors, providing their names and corresponding phone numbers. It also includes the contact information for the organization's Treasurer. The content serves as a directory for key personnel within the SJAA.

articles.title: GROUP PURCHASE OF INEXPENSIVE PERSONAL COMPUTERS
articles.summary: Bruce de Graaf is organizing a group purchase of inexpensive personal computers for SJAA members to achieve significant cost reductions through bulk buying. Information on offerings from Apple, Atari, Commodore, Texas Instruments, and Timex/Sinclair will be presented at the November 6th General Meeting, aiming for complete systems under $600 suitable for software development. Interested members are asked to provide their contact information to facilitate the potential purchase in early December.

articles.title: CLUB TELESCOPES
articles.summary: This article announces that the club's 12.5-inch Dobsonian telescope is currently with Bob Black and will be available for a new two-month loan period starting November 12th; interested members should contact Bob. Additionally, it reports that the club's 6-inch telescope was damaged in an accident and calls for volunteers to assist with its repair.

articles.title: COMET NOTE
articles.summary: This article responds to a previous query regarding instances of amateur astronomers discovering comets while observing Messier objects. The author, Jim McMahon, recalls two such cases: Comet Seki-Lines (1962c) and Comet Bally-Clayton (1968d), providing brief accounts and references to Sky and Telescope articles. While Comet Bally-Clayton was found near the Ring Nebula, the author notes Comet Seki-Lines might not strictly qualify as it was found far from a Messier object.

articles.title: AD
articles.summary: This document is an advertisement for 55-gallon steel drums, available for $5 each. The drums are specifically marketed for their utility in traditional barrel-top mirror grinding, a technique used in amateur telescope making. Interested parties can contact Penny Pinschmidt.

articles.title: Rattlev Rattles
articles.summary: Gerry Rattley provides an update on his astronomical observations in Arizona, detailing his discovery and positive experience at a new dark-sky observing site near Four Peaks in Tonto National Forest. He recounts successful deep-sky observations of various objects, including Comet Austin and challenging galaxies, and describes attending a lively Saguaro Astronomy Club star party near Sedona. The report concludes with a review and error list for the Astronomical League's 'Observe the Herschel Objects' booklet, which he highly recommends.

articles.title: Comet Comments
articles.summary: This article discusses the current visibility of two periodic comets as Comet Austin fades, noting a lack of recent discoveries. It emphasizes a shortage of accurate astrometric positions for comets and encourages amateur astronomers to contribute, referencing relevant articles in 'Sky and Telescope'. The author also shares anecdotes about unusual comet discoveries, including Messier's observation of M1 and an accidental discovery by M.P. Candy.

articles.title: Great Comets of the Past: Comet West (1975n, 1976VI). Discovered by Richard West of the European Southern Observatory (Chile) on November 5th, 1975, in eastern Sagittarius, this comet became one of the brightest and most spectacular of the century. At discovery, Comet West was 13th magnitude. It brightened to 0.0 magnitude in late February 1976, and was even visible in the daytime. In early March, it displayed two tails, each over 25 degrees long, in the pre-dawn sky. Its nucleus split into four parts at about this time. The comet will be back in 15,000 years.
articles.summary: Comet West, discovered in November 1975, became one of the brightest and most spectacular comets of the century. By February 1976, it reached 0.0 magnitude, was visible in daylight, and later displayed two long tails before its nucleus split into four parts. This impressive celestial event is expected to return in 15,000 years.

articles.title: PRODUCT REVIEW
articles.summary: This article reviews the new Unicolor Rapid E-6 Developing Kit for Color Slides, praising its simplified three-step process, reduced development time (20-24 minutes), and improved color rendition, particularly for sky tones. The author notes it's a significant improvement over traditional multi-step E-6 processes and commercial development, making it especially beneficial for astrophotographers.

articles.title: Space Program Update
articles.summary: This article provides an update on various international space programs, detailing the successful use of the Soviet COSPAS/International Sarsat system in multiple air and maritime rescues, despite a high false alarm rate. It also covers the diversion of the ISEE-3 spacecraft for a comet Giacobini-Zinner flyby, the Ariane-1 flight failure, the successful orbiting of Intelsat-5, and Otrag's plans for sounding rockets. Additionally, the update includes details on the upcoming STS-5 mission, NASA's FY'83 funding approval for projects like the Centaur upper stage and a fifth Space Shuttle orbiter, and the selection of Spacelab-1 payload specialists.

articles.title: San Jose Astronomical Association
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) provides a diverse range of activities and services for its members and the public. These offerings include educational opportunities like telescope-making classes and equipment nights, social gatherings such as star parties and picnics, and special events like Astronomy Day and an astronomical auction. The association also acknowledges achievements with awards and disseminates information through its bulletin.

articles.title: Halley's Back!!
articles.summary: Halley's Comet was successfully recovered on October 16, 1982, by a team led by Jewitt and Danielson using the Hale 5-meter telescope at Mt. Palomar with a Space Telescope-developed CCD. The comet was observed in Canis Minor at a magnitude of 24.2, moving as predicted, although initial verification by other observatories and subsequent re-observations by the discovery team faced challenges.

articles.title: SJAA Bulletin
articles.summary: This document serves as the masthead or introductory page for the "SJAA Bulletin," identifying it as a publication of the San Jose Astronomical Association. It provides the association's address and U.S. postage paid information, indicating it is a mailed periodical.

articles.title: SJAA MEETINGS & STAR PARTY SITES
articles.summary: This document, primarily a map, outlines the meeting locations and star party sites for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It serves as a navigational guide, marking various organizational and observing locations within the San Jose area.
